<script type="text/javascript">
var main_site_url = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
var maindomain_lang = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
function getParameterByName(name, url) {
		if(url == null){
		  url = window.location.href;
		}
	    name = name.replace(/[\[\]]/g, '\\$&');
	    var regex = new RegExp('[?&]' + name + '(=([^&#]*)|&|#|$)'),
		results = regex.exec(url);
	    if (!results) return null;
	    if (!results[2]) return '';
	    return decodeURIComponent(results[2].replace(/\+/g, ' '));
	}
	var container_q = getParameterByName('container');
	var d_lang = 'en';	
</script>

<meta property="og:post_image" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/Threat-brief-r3d3.png"/>
<script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https:\/\/schema.org","@type":"BlogPosting","headline":"Threat Brief: SolarStorm and SUNBURST Customer Coverage","name":"Threat Brief: SolarStorm and SUNBURST Customer Coverage","description":"We are tracking the SolarWinds attack, SolarStorm and SUNBURST while working to ensure protections are in place for Palo Alto Networks customers.","url":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/fireeye-solarstorm-sunburst\/","mainEntityOfPage":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/fireeye-solarstorm-sunburst\/","datePublished":"December 14, 2020","articleBody":"Executive Summary\r\nOn Sunday, Dec. 13, FireEye released information related to a breach and data exfiltration originating from an unknown actor FireEye is calling UNC2452. Unit 42 tracks this and related activity as the group named SolarStorm, and has published an ATOM containing the observed techniques, IOCs and relevant courses of action in the Unit 42 ATOM Viewer. According to FireEye, SolarStorm has compromised organizations across the globe via a supply chain attack that consists of a trojanized update file for the SolarWinds Orion Platform.\r\n\r\nFireEye\u2019s blog, \u201cHighly Evasive Attacker Leverages SolarWinds Supply Chain to Compromise Multiple Global Victims with SUNBURST Backdoor,\u201d contains a wealth of useful information, all of which has been analyzed by Unit 42 researchers to help ensure Palo Alto Networks customers are protected.\r\n\r\nAny organization utilizing SolarWinds Orion IT management software is potentially at risk from this threat. These organizations should immediately identify Orion systems in their network, determine if they are compromised with the SUNBURST backdoor and seek out further evidence of compromise. Instructions on how to perform these tasks using the Palo Alto Networks Next Generation Firewall, Cortex XDR and XSOAR are available in this report, as well as additional resources and indicators of compromise (IOCs). Palo Alto Networks has also launched SolarStorm Rapid Response Programs.\u00a0\r\n\r\nThe details of this attack and its impact continue to evolve. We will update this report with new details as they become available.\r\nWhat\u2019s Known About SolarStorm and SUNBURST\r\n\r\n \tSolarStorm specifically targeted supply chains during their attack on SolarWinds\u2019 Orion IT performance and statistics monitoring software.\r\n \tSolarStorm is a highly skilled threat actor, with a significant operational security mindset, as can be observed in its post-exploitation activity.\r\n \tSolarWinds recently filed an SEC report indicating that, while they have over 300,000 customers, fewer than 18,000 customers were running the trojanized version of the Orion software.\r\n \tSolarStorm threat actors created a legitimate digitally signed backdoor, SUNBURST, as a trojanized version of a SolarWinds Orion plug-in. The trojanized software acts as a powerful supply chain infiltration mechanism for delivery.\r\n \tSUNBURST has been observed delivering multiple payloads, mostly focused on memory-only droppers, such as the FireEye-dubbed TEARDROP and Cobalt Strike BEACON.\r\n \tSUNBURST\u2019s command and control (C2) traffic masquerades as legitimate Orion Improvement Program traffic.\r\n \tFireEye has released signatures and specific indicators to help identify SolarStorm\u2019s activity.\r\n\r\nFireEye\u2019s research has been a cornerstone in providing not only useful signatures, but also indicators which help with tracking and hunting for SolarStorm activity. A synopsis of those indicators is included below.\r\nSUNBURST\r\nAt the time of this publication, the Windows Installer Patch file including the trojanized version of the SolarWinds Orion product was still reachable:\r\n\r\nFilename: SolarWinds-Core-v2019.4.5220-Hotfix5.msp\r\nSHA256: d0d626deb3f9484e649294a8dfa814c5568f846d5aa02d4cdad5d041a29d5600\r\n\r\nThis installer contains:\r\n\r\n \tLegitimate SolarWinds Orion update components.\r\n \tA digitally signed SUNBURST backdoor, and its legitimate configuration file:\r\n\r\n \tSHA256: 32519b85c0b422e4656de6e6c41878e95fd95026267daab4215ee59c107d6c77\r\n\r\n \tFilename: SolarWinds.Orion.Core.BusinessLayer.dll\r\n \tCertificate SN: 0f:e9:73:75:20:22:a6:06:ad:f2:a3:6e:34:5d:c0:ed\r\n\r\n\r\n \tSHA256: efbec6863f4330dbb702cc43a85a0a7c29d79fde0f7d66eac9a3be43493cab4f\r\n\r\n \tFilename: SolarWinds.Orion.Core.BusinessLayer.dll.config\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe infrastructure related to this series of attacks includes:\r\n\r\n \tTrojanized update file hosted at:\r\n\r\n \thxxps:\/\/downloads.solarwinds[.]com\/solarwinds\/CatalogResources\/Core\/2019.4\/2019.4.5220.20574\/SolarWinds-Core-v2019.4.5220-Hotfix5.msp\r\n\r\n\r\n \tDGA-generated C2s as subdomains of:\r\n\r\n \tavsvmcloud[.]com\r\n\r\n\r\n \tC2 domains found during SUNBURST incidents, including CNAME records, or subsequent phases of the incident, such as BEACON components:\r\n\r\n \tfreescanonline[.]com\r\n \tdeftsecurity[.]com\r\n \tthedoccloud[.]com\r\n \twebsitetheme[.]com\r\n \thighdatabase[.]com\r\n \tincomeupdate[.]com\r\n \tdatabasegalore[.]com\r\n \tpanhardware[.]com\r\n \tZupertech[.]com\r\n \tVirtualdataserver[.]com\r\n \tdigitalcollege[.]org\r\n \tsolartrackingsystem[.]net\r\n \twebcodez[.]com\r\n \tseobundlekit[.]com\r\n \tvirtualwebdata[.]com\r\n \tlcomputers[.]com\r\n \tavsvmcloud[.]com\r\n \tMobilnweb[.]com\r\n \tkubecloud[.]com\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTEARDROP\r\nSUNBURST deployed several different payloads, and in at least one instance, a memory-only dropper FireEye dubbed TEARDROP to deploy a Cobalt Strike BEACON. During analysis of the information available, Unit 42 identified related activity involving TEARDROP malware that was used to execute a customized Cobalt Strike BEACON. This sample contains a beacon request to the previously unreported domain mobilnweb[.]com.\r\n\r\nThe TEARDROP DLL has a SHA256 of: 118189f90da3788362fe85eafa555298423e21ec37f147f3bf88c61d4cd46c51\r\n\r\nand contains a beacon request for the URI \/2019\/Person-With-Parnters-Brands-Our\/ with the User-Agent Mozilla\/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit\/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome\/85.0.4183.83 Safari\/537.36. Within that same configuration, we also observed an additional URI setting containing the string \/2019\/This-Person-Two-Join-With\/.\r\nProtecting Our Customers\r\nAs of the time of writing, based on signatures and observables that have been released, Palo Alto Networks customers are protected across our product ecosystem, with specific protections deployed or being deployed in the following products and subscriptions for the Next-Generation Firewall (NGFW). It is imperative for customers to employ the best practices for Palo Alto Networks products in order to ensure your appliances are configured in a manner best suited for your protection.\r\n\r\nDue to the nature of these attacks, we recommend our customers perform the following searches immediately. If you are unable, Palo Alto Networks will help you locate SolarWinds Orion servers owned by your organization and assess whether you\u2019ve been compromised free of charge. After we\u2019ve completed our analysis, we\u2019ll provide you with a SolarStorm Assessment Report brought to you by Expanse and Crypsis.\r\nCortex XDR\r\nCortex XDR customers are protected using the product\u2019s WildFire integration, as well as through Local Analysis, the Password Theft Protection module and the Behavioral Threat Protection (BTP) engine. Protections are continually being evaluated, developed and deployed for Cortex XDR.\r\nCortex XDR Managed Threat Hunting\r\nOur Cortex XDR Managed Threat Hunting Team (MTH) has proactively searched all Cortex XDR Pro customer logs to identify potentially impacted organizations and provide them an assessment of their risk.\u00a0Leverage the power of automation with Cortex XSOAR to speed up the discovery of SolarWind installations within your network, uncover signs of potential SolarStorm activity and automate response actions such as the quarantining of compromised endpoints. \u00a0\u00a0\r\nWildFire (NGFW security subscription)\r\nCustomers using WildFire are protected from downloading known SUNBURST backdoor files and Cobalt Strike BEACON files associated with SolarStorm.\r\n\r\nGap analysis and threat hunting leveraging the FireEye-provided Yara signatures and observables has enabled Unit 42 researchers to identify potential malware samples. We continue to seek out new malware associated with SolarStorm, build and deploy protections for them within WildFire. \r\nAutoFocus\r\nAutoFocus customers can track SolarStorm\u2019s activity in the tags SolarStorm, SUPERNOVA, TEARDROP and SUNBURST.\r\nIoT Security (NGFW security subscriptions)\r\nThe IoT Security subscription has the capability of identifying SolarWinds servers. These devices are being added to the IoT Security user portal UI, and the Device-ID attribute will be pushed to PAN-OS. These devices will be displayed to users as \"SolarWinds Network Management Device\" within the IoT Security user portal UI. In PAN-OS, users will see the Device-ID attribute \"Profile\" = \"SolarWinds Network Management Device\". This feature will be enabled for all IoT Security customers this week.\r\nThreat Prevention DNS Security (NGFW security subscriptions)\r\nThreat Prevention and DNS Security provide protection against C2 beacons and associated traffic. Protections are continually being evaluated, developed and deployed for Threat Prevention subscription.\r\n\r\nThe following threat prevention signatures have been added with Content version 8354:\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nSnort Rule\r\nPANW UTID\r\n\r\n\r\nBackdoor.BEACON_5.snort\r\n86237\r\n\r\n\r\nBackdoor.BEACON_6.snort\r\n86238\r\n\r\n\r\nBackdoor.SUNBURST_11.snort\r\n86239\r\n\r\n\r\nBackdoor.SUNBURST_14.snort\r\n86240\r\n\r\n\r\nBackdoor.BEACON_7.snort\r\n86242\r\n\r\n\r\nBackdoor.SUNBURST_12.snort\r\n86243\r\n\r\n\r\nBackdoor.BEACON_8.snort\r\n86244\r\n\r\n\r\nBackdoor.SUNBURST_13.snort\r\n86245\r\n\r\n\r\nBackdoor.SUNBURST_1.snort\r\n86246\r\n\r\n\r\nBackdoor.SUNBURST_10.snort\r\n86247\r\n\r\n\r\nBackdoor.BEACON_2.snort\r\n86248\r\n\r\n\r\nBackdoor.BEACON.snort\r\n86249\r\n\r\n\r\nBackdoor.BEACON_0.snort\r\n86250\r\n\r\n\r\nBackdoor.BEACON_1.snort\r\n86251\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTable 1: Snort to PANW UTID\r\n\r\nURL Filtering (NGFW security subscription)\r\nAs of the time of writing, associated infrastructure described in this blog have accurate verdicts of malware.\r\n\r\nContinue Reading: SolarStorm Response With Next-Generation Firewall\r\n\r\nBack to Top\r\n\r\n\r\nSolarStorm Response With Next-Generation Firewall\r\nIt is possible to identify SolarWinds systems in a network using NGFW traffic monitoring. This section provides details of multiple queries and examples of their outputs.\u00a0It is imperative for customers to employ the best practices for Palo Alto Networks products in order to ensure their appliances are configured in a manner best suited for their protection.\r\n\r\nThe following query filter will identify hosts contacting a server using the SolarWinds App-ID.\u00a0\r\n\r\n&nbsp;\r\n(app eq solarwinds) or (app eq solarwinds-agent) or (app eq solarwinds-base) or (app eq solarwinds-msp-anywhere) or (app eq solarwinds-npm) or (app eq solarwinds-sam)\r\n&nbsp;\r\n\r\nURL Filtering can also help identify compromised servers. This query filter will identify systems connecting to the SolarWinds download server and specifically downloading the SUNBURST plugin update.\u00a0\r\n\r\n&nbsp;\r\n( url contains downloads.solarwinds.com ) or ( url eq 'downloads.solarwinds.com\/solarwinds\/CatalogResources\/Core\/2019.4\/2019.4.5220.20574\/SolarWinds-Core-v2019.4.5220-Hotfix5.msp' )\r\n&nbsp;\r\n\r\n\r\nThe following URL Filtering query will identify traffic to the known SUNBURST command and control domains:\u00a0\r\n\r\n&nbsp;\r\n( url contains avsvmcloud.com ) or ( url contains freescanonline.com ) or ( url contains deftsecurity.com ) or ( url contains thedoccloud.com ) or ( url contains websitetheme.com ) or ( url contains highdatabase.com ) or ( url contains incomeupdate.com ) or ( url contains databasegalore.com ) or ( url contains panhardware.com ) or ( url contains zupertech.com ) or ( url contains virtualdataserver.com ) or ( url contains digitalcollege.org)\r\n&nbsp;\r\n\r\nFile Blocking will identify hosts that have downloaded the known filenames associated with the\u00a0 SUNBURST plugin update.\u00a0\r\n\r\n&nbsp;\r\n( filename eq SolarWinds-Core-v2019.4.5220-Hotfix5.msp ) and ( threat_name eq 'Windows Installer Patch MSP File' )\r\n&nbsp;\r\n\r\nThreat logs can expose DNS queries that indicate SUNBURST command and control traffic. The following filter identifies known domain names used by the backdoor.\u00a0\r\n\r\n&nbsp;\r\n( threat_name eq 'generic:avsvmcloud.com' ) or ( threat_name eq 'generic:freescanonline.com' ) or ( threat_name eq 'generic:deftsecurity.com' ) or ( threat_name eq 'generic:thedoccloud.com' ) or ( threat_name eq 'generic:websitetheme.com' ) or ( threat_name eq 'generic:highdatabase.com') or ( threat_name eq 'generic:incomeupdate.com' ) or ( threat_name eq 'generic:databasegalore.com' ) or ( threat_name eq 'generic:panhardware.com' ) or ( threat_name eq 'generic:zupertech.com' ) or ( threat_name eq 'generic:virtualdataserver.com' ) or ( threat_name eq 'generic:digitalcollege.org' )\r\n&nbsp;\r\n\r\nThe following v9.x query can also be used to expose relative DNS queries:\r\n\r\n&nbsp;\r\n( url eq 'Suspicious DNS Query (generic:avsvmcloud.com)' ) or ( url eq 'Suspicious DNS Query (generic:freescanonline.com)' ) or ( url eq 'Suspicious DNS Query (generic:deftsecurity.com)' ) or ( url eq 'Suspicious DNS Query (generic:thedoccloud.com)' ) or ( url eq 'Suspicious DNS Query (generic:websitetheme.com)' ) or ( url eq 'Suspicious DNS Query (generic:highdatabase.com)' ) or ( url eq 'Suspicious DNS Query (generic:incomeupdate.com)' ) or ( url eq 'Suspicious DNS Query (generic:databasegalore.com)' ) or ( url eq 'Suspicious DNS Query (generic:panhardware.com)' ) or ( url eq 'Suspicious DNS Query (generic:zupertech.com)' ) or ( url eq 'Suspicious DNS Query (generic:virtualdataserver.com)' ) or ( url eq 'Suspicious DNS Query (generic:digitalcollege.org)' ) or ( url eq 'Suspicious DNS Query (generic:solartrackingsystem.net)' ) or ( url eq 'Suspicious DNS Query (generic:webcodez.com)' ) or ( url eq 'Suspicious DNS Query (generic:seobundlekit.com)' ) or ( url eq 'Suspicious DNS Query (generic:virtualwebdata.com)' ) or ( url eq 'Suspicious DNS Query (generic:lcomputers.com)' ) or ( url eq 'Suspicious DNS Query (generic:mobilenweb.com)' )  or ( url eq 'Suspicious DNS Query (generic:kubecloud.com)' )\r\n&nbsp;\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nWildFire and Threat Prevention identify the known SUNBURST backdoor files. The following filter will identify the specific threats associated with SUNBURST in the Threat log.\u00a0\r\n\r\n&nbsp;\r\n(name-of-threatid eq 392983194) or (name-of-threatid eq 392972205) or (name-of-threatid eq 393078495)\r\n&nbsp;\r\n\r\nThe following filter will identify known SUNBURST and TEARDROP files submitted to WildFire in the WildFire submissions log:\u00a0\r\n\r\n&nbsp;\r\n( filedigest eq ce77d116a074dab7a22a0fd4f2c1ab475f16eec42e1ded3c0b0aa8211fe858d6 ) or ( filedigest eq 019085a76ba7126fff22770d71bd901c325fc68ac55aa743327984e89f4b0134 ) or ( filedigest eq 32519b85c0b422e4656de6e6c41878e95fd95026267daab4215ee59c107d6c77 ) or ( filedigest eq 118189f90da3788362fe85eafa555298423e21ec37f147f3bf88c61d4cd46c51 )\r\n&nbsp;\r\n\r\nThreat Prevention can detect command and control traffic from SUNBURST as well as the Cobalt Strike Beacon used by SolarStorm. The following filter will identify this command and control traffic in the Threat log.\r\n\r\n&nbsp;\r\n(name-of-threatid eq 86237) or (name-of-threatid eq 86238) or (name-of-threatid eq 86239) or (name-of-threatid eq 86240) or (name-of-threatid eq 86242) or (name-of-threatid eq 86243) or (name-of-threatid eq 86244) or (name-of-threatid eq 86245) or (name-of-threatid eq 86246) or (name-of-threatid eq 86247) or (name-of-threatid eq 86248) or (name-of-threatid eq 86249) or (name-of-threatid eq 86250) or (name-of-threatid eq 86251)\r\n&nbsp;\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nContinue reading: SolarStorm Response With Cortex XDR and\/or Cortex XSOAR\r\n\r\nBack to Top\r\n\r\n\r\nSolarStorm Response With Cortex XDR\r\nCustomers running Cortex XDR Pro can leverage the product's existing alert sets and hunt for related activity.\r\n\r\nPlease note that the Cortex XDR Managed Threat Hunting Service scanned all data available for all XDR Pro customers \u2013 even those who are not currently subscribed to the service \u2013 and sent an impact report based on the findings to all XDR Pro customers.\r\n\r\nFirstly, to understand if the organization is breached, we can search for SolarWinds installations based either on endpoint or network data using the following query, leveraging AppID and known SolarWinds domains (For updated and copy\/paste-friendly versions, all queries described in this section are available on GitHub.):\r\ndataset = xdr_data|filter arraystring(action_app_id_transitions, \",\") contains \r\n\"solarwinds\" or dst_action_external_hostname = \"api.solarwinds.com\"  or \r\naction_external_hostname = \"api.solarwinds.com\"| fields agent_hostname, \r\naction_local_ip|dedup agent_hostname, action_local_ip\r\n\r\n\r\nTo verify if you have been a victim of the attack, assuming there is a Palo Alto Networks NGFW or an agent installed on a SolarWinds server, you can run a query to check for known IOCs.\r\n\r\nIt\u2019s possible to load known IOCs, such as IPs, domains, hashes and filenames, into XDR and it will automatically run a backwards scan, resulting in alerts on historic data.\r\n\r\nTo do this, create one file with all the IOCs:\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nGo to the Rules \u2192 IOC page and click on \u201c+ Add IOC\u201d and then select \u201cUpload File\u201d in the popup view.\u00a0\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nAdd your file, assign a severity, reputation, reliability and expiration date, then click \u201cUpload.\u201d\r\n\r\nAfter loading, you\u2019ll see the \u201cBackwards Scan Status\u201d as pending and \u201c# Of Hits\u201d as 0. A few minutes later, you\u2019ll see the status change to \u201cDone\u201d with a timestamp.\r\n\r\nIf any matches were found, you\u2019ll see the \u201c# Of Hits\u201d change from 0 to the amount of hits the system found per IOC.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nYou can right-click on the IOC and select \u201cView Associated Alerts\u201d to pivot to the alert page.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nWhenever you see this icon  next to a rule name in XDR, it means that this is a historic match based on backwards scanning on an IOC or Behavioral IOC.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nYou can right-click on the alert to analyze it and drill down into it.\r\n\r\nVice versa, you can run an XQL query with the known IOCs. This will look across file writes, module loads, process executions, network traffic and DNS queries coming either through NGFW, Cortex Agent or any third party network traffic that is ingested into the Cortex XDR Data Lake:\r\ndataset = xdr_data|filter action_file_sha256 in (\"32519b85c0b422e4656de6e6c41878e95fd95026267daab4215ee59c107d6c77\", \"dab758bf98d9b36fa057a66cd0284737abf89857b73ca89280267ee7caf62f3b\", \"eb6fab5a2964c5817fb239a7a5079cabca0a00464fb3e07155f28b0a57a2c0ed\", \"c09040d35630d75dfef0f804f320f8b3d16a481071076918e9b236a321c1ea77\", \"ac1b2b89e60707a20e9eb1ca480bc3410ead40643b386d624c5d21b47c02917c\", \"019085a76ba7126fff22770d71bd901c325fc68ac55aa743327984e89f4b0134\", \"ce77d116a074dab7a22a0fd4f2c1ab475f16eec42e1ded3c0b0aa8211fe858d6\", \"a25cadd48d70f6ea0c4a241d99c5241269e6faccb4054e62d16784640f8e53bc\", \"d3c6785e18fba3749fb785bc313cf8346182f532c59172b69adfb31b96a5d0af\",\r\n\u201c118189f90da3788362fe85eafa555298423e21ec37f147f3bf88c61d4cd46c51\u201d) or action_module_sha256 in (\"32519b85c0b422e4656de6e6c41878e95fd95026267daab4215ee59c107d6c77\", \"dab758bf98d9b36fa057a66cd0284737abf89857b73ca89280267ee7caf62f3b\", \"eb6fab5a2964c5817fb239a7a5079cabca0a00464fb3e07155f28b0a57a2c0ed\", \"c09040d35630d75dfef0f804f320f8b3d16a481071076918e9b236a321c1ea77\", \"ac1b2b89e60707a20e9eb1ca480bc3410ead40643b386d624c5d21b47c02917c\", \"019085a76ba7126fff22770d71bd901c325fc68ac55aa743327984e89f4b0134\", \"ce77d116a074dab7a22a0fd4f2c1ab475f16eec42e1ded3c0b0aa8211fe858d6\", \"a25cadd48d70f6ea0c4a241d99c5241269e6faccb4054e62d16784640f8e53bc\", \"d3c6785e18fba3749fb785bc313cf8346182f532c59172b69adfb31b96a5d0af\",\r\n\u201c118189f90da3788362fe85eafa555298423e21ec37f147f3bf88c61d4cd46c51\u201d) or action_process_image_sha256 in (\"32519b85c0b422e4656de6e6c41878e95fd95026267daab4215ee59c107d6c77\", \"dab758bf98d9b36fa057a66cd0284737abf89857b73ca89280267ee7caf62f3b\", \"eb6fab5a2964c5817fb239a7a5079cabca0a00464fb3e07155f28b0a57a2c0ed\", \"c09040d35630d75dfef0f804f320f8b3d16a481071076918e9b236a321c1ea77\", \"ac1b2b89e60707a20e9eb1ca480bc3410ead40643b386d624c5d21b47c02917c\", \"019085a76ba7126fff22770d71bd901c325fc68ac55aa743327984e89f4b0134\", \"ce77d116a074dab7a22a0fd4f2c1ab475f16eec42e1ded3c0b0aa8211fe858d6\", \"a25cadd48d70f6ea0c4a241d99c5241269e6faccb4054e62d16784640f8e53bc\", \"d3c6785e18fba3749fb785bc313cf8346182f532c59172b69adfb31b96a5d0af\",\r\n\u201c118189f90da3788362fe85eafa555298423e21ec37f147f3bf88c61d4cd46c51\u201d) or dst_action_external_hostname ~= \".*freescanonline.com|.*deftsecurity.com|.*thedoccloud.com|.*websitetheme.com|.*highdatabase.com|.*incomeupdate.com|.*databasegalore.com|.*panhardware.com|.*zupertech.com|.*virtualdataserver.com|.*digitalcollege.org|.*avsvmcloud.com|.*solartrackingsystem.net|.*webcodez.com|.*seobundlekit.com|.*virtualwebdata.com|.*lcomputers.com|.*mobilnweb.com|.*kubecloud.com\" or action_external_hostname ~= \".*freescanonline.com|.*deftsecurity.com|.*thedoccloud.com|.*websitetheme.com|.*highdatabase.com|.*incomeupdate.com|.*databasegalore.com|.*panhardware.com|.*zupertech.com|.*virtualdataserver.com|.*digitalcollege.org|.*avsvmcloud.com|.*solartrackingsystem.net|.*webcodez.com|.*seobundlekit.com|.*virtualwebdata.com|.*lcomputers.com|.*mobilnweb.com|.*kubecloud.com\" or dns_query_name ~= \".*freescanonline.com|.*deftsecurity.com|.*thedoccloud.com|.*websitetheme.com|.*highdatabase.com|.*incomeupdate.com|.*databasegalore.com|.*panhardware.com|.*zupertech.com|.*virtualdataserver.com|.*digitalcollege.org|.*avsvmcloud.com|.*solartrackingsystem.net|.*webcodez.com|.*seobundlekit.com|.*virtualwebdata.com|.*lcomputers.com|.*mobilnweb.com|.*kubecloud.com\"\r\n| fields agent_hostname, causality_actor_process_image_path, actor_process_image_path,action_external_hostname, action_file_path, action_module_path, dst_action_external_hostname, dns_query_name |dedup agent_hostname, causality_actor_process_image_path, \r\nactor_process_image_path,action_external_hostname, action_file_path, action_module_path, dst_action_external_hostname, dns_query_name\r\n\r\n\r\nAs attackers might have used different domains and hashes, we suggest hunting for behavior from the infected SolarWinds executable in addition to searching for known IOCs.\r\n\r\nWe suggest using the following queries to verify that no suspicious activity took place:\r\n\r\n1. Look at alerts and incidents that have any SolarWinds binary attached to them or any alerts related to Cobalt Strike, as these attackers have been seen using the framework:\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n&nbsp;\r\n\r\n2. Look for binary and scripting files dropped from the infected SolarWinds process:\r\ndataset = xdr_data|filter\u00a0event_type\u00a0= FILE and\u00a0event_sub_type\u00a0= FILE_WRITE and\r\nlowercase(actor_process_image_name) = \u201csolarwinds.businesslayerhost*.exe\u201d and\r\naction_file_extension\u00a0in\u00a0(\u201cdll\u201d, \u201cexe\u201d, \u201csys\u201d, \u201cmsi\u201d, \u201cscr\u201d, \u201cocx\u201d, \u201ccmd\u201d, \u201cbat\u201d,\r\n\u201cps1\u201d, \u201cvba\u201d, \u201cvbs\u201d, \u201ccom\u201d, \u201ccpl\u201d, \u201cbin\u201d, \u201cvbe\u201d)| fields\r\ncausality_actor_process_image_path,\u00a0actor_process_image_path,\u00a0agent_hostname,\r\naction_file_path,\u00a0action_file_name|dedup\u00a0causality_actor_process_image_path,\r\nactor_process_image_path,\u00a0agent_hostname,\u00a0action_file_name\r\n\r\n\r\n3. Look for signs of the infected SolarWinds process accessing non-SolarWinds domains:\r\ndataset = xdr_data|filter event_type = NETWORK\u00a0 and\r\nlowercase(actor_process_image_name) = \"solarwinds.businesslayerhost*.exe\" and\r\naction_external_hostname not contains \"solarwinds.com\" and action_external_hostname\r\n!= \"*.local\" | fields causality_actor_process_image_path, actor_process_image_path,\r\nagent_hostname, action_remote_ip, action_external_hostname|dedup\r\ncausality_actor_process_image_path, actor_process_image_path, agent_hostname, action_remote_ip, action_external_hostname\r\n\r\n\r\n4. Look for the infected SolarWinds process running Windows Management Instrumentation queries:\r\ndataset = xdr_data|filter event_type = RPC_CALL and\r\nlowercase(actor_process_image_name) = \"solarwinds.businesslayerhost*.exe\" and\r\naction_rpc_interface_name = \"IWbemServices\"|fields agent_hostname,\r\naction_rpc_func_str_call_fields\r\n5. Look for the infected SolarWinds process modifying or creating a service:\r\ndataset = xdr_data|filter event_type = REGISTRY and\r\nlowercase(actor_process_image_name) = \"solarwinds.businesslayerhost*.exe\" and\r\naction_registry_key_name = \"HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\\SYSTEM\\*\\Services\\*\" | fields\r\ncausality_actor_process_image_path, actor_process_image_path, agent_hostname,\r\naction_registry_key_name, action_registry_value_name, action_registry_data |dedup\r\ncausality_actor_process_image_path, actor_process_image_path, agent_hostname,\r\naction_registry_key_name, action_registry_value_name, action_registry_data\r\n\r\n6. We can hunt down backdoored DLLs which initiated network connections and look for any suspicious connection that involves DGA domains:\r\ndataset = xdr_data\r\n| filter (event_type = NETWORK or event_type = STORY) and\r\nlowercase(actor_process_image_name) contains \"solarwinds.businesslayerhost\"\r\n| filter action_external_hostname not contains \"solarwinds\" and\r\naction_external_hostname not contains \".local\"\r\n| fields agent_hostname, agent_id, actor_process_instance_id,\r\nactor_process_image_name, action_external_hostname, dst_action_external_hostname,\r\ndns_query_name\r\n| join (dataset = xdr_data\r\n       | filter event_sub_type = LOAD_IMAGE_MODULE and\r\n                                   action_module_sha256 in\r\n(\"019085a76ba7126fff22770d71bd901c325fc68ac55aa743327984e89f4b0134\",\r\n\"32519b85c0b422e4656de6e6c41878e95fd95026267daab4215ee59c107d6c77\",\r\n\"ce77d116a074dab7a22a0fd4f2c1ab475f16eec42e1ded3c0b0aa8211fe858d6\")\r\n                                   and lowercase(actor_process_image_name) contains\r\n\"solarwinds.businesslayerhost\"\r\n       | fields agent_hostname, agent_id, actor_process_instance_id,\r\nactor_process_image_name, action_module_sha256, action_module_path) as modules\r\n       modules.actor_process_instance_id = actor_process_instance_id and\r\nmodules.agent_id = agent_id\r\n       | fields agent_hostname, agent_id, actor_process_instance_id,\r\nactor_process_image_name, action_module_sha256, action_module_path,\r\naction_external_hostname, dst_action_external_hostname, dns_query_name\r\n       | dedup agent_hostname, agent_id, actor_process_instance_id,\r\nactor_process_image_name, action_module_path, action_external_hostname,\r\ndst_action_external_hostname, dns_query_name\r\n7. Hunt based on the known backdoor named pipe:\r\ndataset = xdr_data\r\n| filter action_file_device_type = 1 and action_file_name != null and\r\nlowercase(actor_process_image_name) contains \"solarwinds.businesslayerhost\"\r\n| filter action_file_name = \"583da945-62af-10e8-4902-a8f205c72b2e\"\r\n| fields agent_hostname, actor_process_instance_id, actor_process_image_name,\r\naction_file_name\r\n| dedup actor_process_instance_id, actor_process_image_name, action_file_name\r\nXDR 2.6.5, the latest release, now opens up new abilities to query Azure Active Directory (AD) audit logs to hunt for activities that the threat actor has done after gaining access and leveraging the backdoor to get credentials. You can use the following queries to hunt for such activity assuming you have configured your XDR using our admin guide:\r\n\r\n1. Hunt for Azure AD service account created or modified:\r\npreset = msft_azure_ad_audit \/\/ go over azure ad audit logs\r\n| filter activityDisplayName IN (\"Add service principal credentials\", \"Add service principal\")\r\nAND result = \"success\" \/\/ find cases where someone adds SPNs to an account\r\n2. Hunt for Azure AD application sharing with additional tenants:\r\npreset = msft_azure_ad_audit\u00a0 \/\/ go over azure ad audit logs\r\n| filter activityDisplayName = \"Update application\"\r\nAND operationType=\"Update\"\r\nand result=\"success\"\r\nand modifiedDisplayName = \"AvailableToOtherTenants\"\u00a0 \/\/ find cases where someone grants permission to access an app from another azure ad tenant\r\n3. Hunt for Azure AD custom unverified domain was added:\r\npreset = msft_azure_ad_audit \/\/ go over azure ad audit logs\r\n| filter activityDisplayName = \"Add unverified domain\" AND result = \"success\"\u00a0 \/\/ find cases\r\nwhere someone added a custom domain to the azure ad env\r\n4. Hunt for SSO being disabled for a domain:\r\npreset = msft_azure_ad_audit \/\/ go over azure ad audit logs\r\n| filter activityDisplayName = \"Disable Desktop Sso for a specific domain\" AND result =\r\n\"success\" \/\/ remove need for SSO on desktop devices\r\n5. Hunt for domain federation settings modified:\r\npreset = msft_azure_ad_audit \/\/ go over azure ad audit logs\r\n| filter activityDisplayName = \"Set federation settings on domain\"\r\n6. Hunt for cases where mail permissions were added to a service principal:\r\npreset = msft_azure_ad_audit \/\/ go over azure ad audit logs\r\n| filter activityDisplayName IN (\"Add app role assignment to service\r\nprincipal\", \"Add delegated permission grant\", \"Add application\" ) and\r\n        modifiedPropertyNewValue ~= \"(Mail.Read|Mail.ReadWrite)\" and\r\n        modifiedPropertyOldValue not contains \"Mail.Read\" \/\/ find\r\ncases where mail read was added as a permission to another account\r\nThese queries are also waiting in our query center for easy execution:\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n(See the Appendix for IOCs, or find them on GitHub.)\r\nSolarStorm Response With Cortex XSOAR\r\nCortex XSOAR has launched a rapid response playbook to speed up the discovery of SolarWind installations within your network, uncover signs of a potential SolarStorm activity and automate response actions such as the quarantining of compromised endpoints.\r\n\r\nContinue reading: Conclusion, Additional Resources and IOCs\r\n\r\nBack to Top\r\n\r\n\r\nConclusion\r\nThe protections in place for our customers are continually being updated for this related threat activity and for all threats that are identified in the wild. Customers should know that Unit 42 researchers are working diligently to ensure protections are in place for our entire product ecosystem.\r\n\r\nWhile Palo Alto Networks has deployed effective countermeasures to help protect customers, there are some additional safeguards organizations leveraging SolarWinds can take:\r\n\r\n \tIdentify all SolarWinds servers inside your organization, isolate them from the rest of the network and block internet-facing traffic from them.\r\n \tSearch for indicators of the SUNBURST, TEARDROP and BEACON malware in network and endpoint logs.\r\n \tEvaluate SolarWinds\u2019 Guidelines for future system updates, found in the Additional Resources section\r\n\r\nThere\u2019s been a litany of press surrounding this event, with several sources releasing information, including SolarWinds. A selection of key information is listed in the section below.\r\nAppendix\r\nAdditional Resources\r\n\r\n \tCISA released announcement\r\n \tSolarWinds Security Advisory\r\n \tSecuring your Orion Platform instance\r\n \tSolarWinds SEC filing\r\n \tThreat Brief: FireEye Red Team Tool Breach\r\n \tA Timeline Perspective of the SolarStorm Supply Chain Attack\r\n\r\nIndicators of Compromise (IOCs)\r\nfreescanonline[.]com\r\n\r\ndeftsecurity[.]com\r\n\r\nthedoccloud[.]com\r\n\r\nwebsitetheme[.]com\r\n\r\nhighdatabase[.]com\r\n\r\nincomeupdate[.]com\r\n\r\ndatabasegalore[.]com\r\n\r\npanhardware[.]com\r\n\r\nzupertech[.]com\r\n\r\nVirtualwebdata[.]com\r\n\r\nvirtualdataserver[.]com\r\n\r\ndigitalcollege[.]org\r\n\r\nlcomputers[.]com\r\n\r\nwebcodez[.]com\r\n\r\ndeftsecurity[.]com\r\n\r\nglobalnetworkissues[.]com\r\n\r\nkubecloud[.]com\r\n\r\nseobundlekit[.]com\r\n\r\nsolartrackingsystem[.]net\r\n\r\na7240d8a7aee872c08b915a58976a1ddee2ff5a8a679f78ec1c7cf528f40deed\r\n\r\n5fabe36fb1da700a1c418e184c2e5332fe2f8c575c6148bdac360f69f91be6c2\r\n\r\ne9e646a9dba31a8e3debf4202ed34b0b22c483f1aca75ffa43e684cb417837fa\r\n\r\nb9cf6fbde82839e15413595a50aeb1044a8f4e3be180c42436e11675c22cf914\r\n\r\n02f47b88caa73d607d820d258cd9f167ed266af99a62e10c9220a7e0228cf53e\r\n\r\nc0fc006ffa92d0111197f8e3a1d2ba06a326eddc3d0b28111727df8e52805cf8\r\n\r\nb05640e8f35761435e3cf22524136808a891304f10ec9f354eb9decc43cb617e\r\n\r\n32519b85c0b422e4656de6e6c41878e95fd95026267daab4215ee59c107d6c77\r\n\r\nce77d116a074dab7a22a0fd4f2c1ab475f16eec42e1ded3c0b0aa8211fe858d6\r\n\r\n019085a76ba7126fff22770d71bd901c325fc68ac55aa743327984e89f4b0134\r\n\r\nac1b2b89e60707a20e9eb1ca480bc3410ead40643b386d624c5d21b47c02917c\r\n\r\nc15abaf51e78ca56c0376522d699c978217bf041a3bd3c71d09193efa5717c71\r\n\r\n6e4050c6a2d2e5e49606d96dd2922da480f2e0c70082cc7e54449a7dc0d20f8d\r\n\r\n118189f90da3788362fe85eafa555298423e21ec37f147f3bf88c61d4cd46c51\r\n\r\nUpdated :root{--wp--preset--aspect-ratio--square: 1;--wp--preset--aspect-ratio--4-3: 4/3;--wp--preset--aspect-ratio--3-4: 3/4;--wp--preset--aspect-ratio--3-2: 3/2;--wp--preset--aspect-ratio--2-3: 2/3;--wp--preset--aspect-ratio--16-9: 16/9;--wp--preset--aspect-ratio--9-16: 9/16;--wp--preset--color--black: #000000;--wp--preset--color--cyan-bluish-gray: #abb8c3;--wp--preset--color--white: #ffffff;--wp--preset--color--pale-pink: #f78da7;--wp--preset--color--vivid-red: #cf2e2e;--wp--preset--color--luminous-vivid-orange: #ff6900;--wp--preset--color--luminous-vivid-amber: #fcb900;--wp--preset--color--light-green-cyan: #7bdcb5;--wp--preset--color--vivid-green-cyan: #00d084;--wp--preset--color--pale-cyan-blue: #8ed1fc;--wp--preset--color--vivid-cyan-blue: #0693e3;--wp--preset--color--vivid-purple: #9b51e0;--wp--preset--gradient--vivid-cyan-blue-to-vivid-purple: linear-gradient(135deg,rgba(6,147,227,1) 0%,rgb(155,81,224) 100%);--wp--preset--gradient--light-green-cyan-to-vivid-green-cyan: linear-gradient(135deg,rgb(122,220,180) 0%,rgb(0,208,130) 100%);--wp--preset--gradient--luminous-vivid-amber-to-luminous-vivid-orange: linear-gradient(135deg,rgba(252,185,0,1) 0%,rgba(255,105,0,1) 100%);--wp--preset--gradient--luminous-vivid-orange-to-vivid-red: linear-gradient(135deg,rgba(255,105,0,1) 0%,rgb(207,46,46) 100%);--wp--preset--gradient--very-light-gray-to-cyan-bluish-gray: linear-gradient(135deg,rgb(238,238,238) 0%,rgb(169,184,195) 100%);--wp--preset--gradient--cool-to-warm-spectrum: linear-gradient(135deg,rgb(74,234,220) 0%,rgb(151,120,209) 20%,rgb(207,42,186) 40%,rgb(238,44,130) 60%,rgb(251,105,98) 80%,rgb(254,248,76) 100%);--wp--preset--gradient--blush-light-purple: linear-gradient(135deg,rgb(255,206,236) 0%,rgb(152,150,240) 100%);--wp--preset--gradient--blush-bordeaux: linear-gradient(135deg,rgb(254,205,165) 0%,rgb(254,45,45) 50%,rgb(107,0,62) 100%);--wp--preset--gradient--luminous-dusk: 0.44rem;--wp--preset--spacing--30: 0.67rem;--wp--preset--spacing--40: 1rem;--wp--preset--spacing--50: 1.5rem;--wp--preset--spacing--60: 2.25rem;--wp--preset--spacing--70: 3.38rem;--wp--preset--spacing--80: 5.06rem;--wp--preset--shadow--natural: 6px 6px 9px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.2);--wp--preset--shadow--deep: 12px 12px 50px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.4);--wp--preset--shadow--sharp: 6px     <script type="text/javascript">
    ;(function(win, doc, style, timeout) {
    var STYLE_ID = 'at-body-style';
    function getParent() {
    return doc.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];
    }
    function addStyle(parent, id, def) {
        if (!parent) {
        return;
        }
        var style = doc.createElement('style');
        style.id = id;
        style.innerHTML = def;
        parent.appendChild(style);
    }
    function removeStyle(parent, id) {
        if (!parent) {
            return;
        }
        var style = doc.getElementById(id);
        if (!style) {
            return;
        }
        parent.removeChild(style);
    }
    addStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID, style);
    setTimeout(function() {
    removeStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID);
    }, timeout);
    }(window, document, "body {visibility:hidden !important}", 3000));
    </script>

<script type="text/javascript">
var isIE11 = !!navigator.userAgent.match(/Trident.*rv\:11\./);
if(isIE11){
    var polyfill = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/scripts/polyfill.min.js';
    document.write('<script type="text/javascript" src="'+polyfill+'">\x3C/script>');
}
    /**
 * String.prototype.replaceAll() polyfill
 * https://gomakethings.com/how-to-replace-a-section-of-a-string-with-another-one-with-vanilla-js/
 * @author Chris Ferdinandi
 * @license MIT
 */
if (!String.prototype.replaceAll) {
	String.prototype.replaceAll = function(str, newStr){
		// If a regex pattern
		if (Object.prototype.toString.call(str).toLowerCase() === '[object regexp]') {
			return this.replace(str, newStr);
		}
		// If a string
		return this.replace(new RegExp(str, 'g'), newStr);
	};
}

    /*! lozad.js - v1.16.0 - 2020-09-06 */
!function(t,e){"object"==typeof exports&&"undefined"!=typeof module?module.exports=e():"function"==typeof define&&define.amd?define(e):t.lozad=e()}(this,function(){"use strict";
/**
   * Detect IE browser
   * @const {boolean}
   * @private
   */var g="undefined"!=typeof document&&document.documentMode,f={rootMargin:"0px",threshold:0,load:function(t){if("picture"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()){var e=t.querySelector("img"),r=!1;null===e&&(e=document.createElement("img"),r=!0),g&&t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")&&(e.src=t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")),t.getAttribute("data-alt")&&(e.alt=t.getAttribute("data-alt")),r&&t.append(e)}if("video"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()&&!t.getAttribute("data-src")&&t.children){for(var a=t.children,o=void 0,i=0;i<=a.length-1;i++)(o=a[i].getAttribute("data-src"))&&(a[i].src=o);t.load()}t.getAttribute("data-poster")&&(t.poster=t.getAttribute("data-poster")),t.getAttribute("data-src")&&(t.src=t.getAttribute("data-src")),t.getAttribute("data-srcset")&&t.setAttribute("srcset",t.getAttribute("data-srcset"));var n=",";if(t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")&&(n=t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")),t.getAttribute("data-background-image"))t.style.backgroundImage="url('"+t.getAttribute("data-background-image").split(n).join("'),url('")+"')";else if(t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set")){var d=t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set").split(n),u=d[0].substr(0,d[0].indexOf(" "))||d[0];// Substring before ... 1x
u=-1===u.indexOf("url(")?"url("+u+")":u,1===d.length?t.style.backgroundImage=u:t.setAttribute("style",(t.getAttribute("style")||"")+"background-image: "+u+"; background-image: -webkit-image-set("+d+"); background-image: image-set("+d+")")}t.getAttribute("data-toggle-class")&&t.classList.toggle(t.getAttribute("data-toggle-class"))},loaded:function(){}};function A(t){t.setAttribute("data-loaded",!0)}var m=function(t){return"true"===t.getAttribute("data-loaded")},v=function(t){var e=1<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[1]?arguments[1]:document;return t instanceof Element?[t]:t instanceof NodeList?t:e.querySelectorAll(t)};return function(){var r,a,o=0<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[0]?arguments[0]:".lozad",t=1<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[1]?arguments[1]:{},e=Object.assign({},f,t),i=e.root,n=e.rootMargin,d=e.threshold,u=e.load,g=e.loaded,s=void 0;"undefined"!=typeof window&&window.IntersectionObserver&&(s=new IntersectionObserver((r=u,a=g,function(t,e){t.forEach(function(t){(0<t.intersectionRatio||t.isIntersecting)&&(e.unobserve(t.target),m(t.target)||(r(t.target),A(t.target),a(t.target)))})}),{root:i,rootMargin:n,threshold:d}));for(var c,l=v(o,i),b=0;b<l.length;b++)(c=l[b]).getAttribute("data-placeholder-background")&&(c.style.background=c.getAttribute("data-placeholder-background"));return{observe:function(){for(var t=v(o,i),e=0;e<t.length;e++)m(t[e])||(s?s.observe(t[e]):(u(t[e]),A(t[e]),g(t[e])))},triggerLoad:function(t){m(t)||(u(t),A(t),g(t))},observer:s}}});

</script>

  </div>
</header>

<nav id="navigation" class="site-nav collapse d-sm-block pb-20 mt-sm-10"  style="display: none!important;">
  <div class="container px-sm-30">
    <ul id="menu-primary-navigation" class="main-menu d-sm-flex font-weight-medium"><li id="menu-item-97290" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-97290"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tools/">Tools</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-41" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-41"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/atoms/">ATOMs</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-119884" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-119884"><a target="_blank" href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42">Security Consulting</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-81229" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-81229"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/about-unit-42/">About Us</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-121229" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-121229"><a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html"><b style="color:#C84727">Under Attack?</b></a></li>
</ul>  </div>
</nav>
<div class="panClean pan-template-home" id="main-nav-menu-cont" style="display:none;">
    <div class="cleanHeader mainNavigationComp baseComponent parbase">
        <div class="productNav2021Component dark default" id="PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC">
        </div>
  </div>
<div class="cleanTopHtml htmlComp baseComponent parbase"><div class="base-component-spacer spacer-none  "></div>
</div>
</div>
<!--  Start: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->
<script type="text/javascript">
	function getCookie(cname) {
	 	var name = cname + "=";
  		var decodedCookie = decodeURIComponent(document.cookie);
		var ca = decodedCookie.split(';');
  		for(var i = 0; i <ca.length; i++) {
    			var c = ca[i];
    			while (c.charAt(0) == ' ') {
     				 c = c.substring(1);
    			}
    			if (c.indexOf(name) == 0) {
    				 return c.substring(name.length, c.length);
    			}
  		}
  		return "";
	}

	var referer = "";//sessionStorage.container;
	var pcontainer = sessionStorage.getItem("container");
	var searchResultsPagePath = "";
	if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Prisma')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Prisma' ;
	}        
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Cortex')!=-1)){
            if( pcontainer.indexOf('CloudCortex') != -1){
                referer = 'CloudCortex' ;
            }
            else{
                referer = 'Cortex' ;
            }	    
	}
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Sase')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Sase' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Unit')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Unit' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Ngfw')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Ngfw' ;
	}
        var fromRef = document.referrer;
        var nContainer = getCookie("navContainer");
        if(nContainer){//If user is coming from main site, we need to reset the container		
		if(fromRef  && fromRef.indexOf("prismacloud.io")!=-1){
                        referer = 'Prisma' ;
                        sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                } else if(fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.com")!=-1 || fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.jp")!=-1 ){
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Prisma') != -1){
                            referer = 'Prisma' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                        }
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Cortex') != -1){
                            if( nContainer.indexOf('CloudCortex') != -1){
                                referer = 'CloudCortex';
                                sessionStorage.setItem("container","CloudCortex");
                            }
                            else{
                                referer = 'Cortex';
                                sessionStorage.setItem("container","Cortex");
                            }                            
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Sase') != -1){
                            referer = 'Sase' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Sase");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Unit') != -1){
                            referer = 'Unit' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Ngfw') != -1){
                            referer = 'Ngfw' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Ngfw");
                        }
			document.cookie = 'navContainer=; path=/; domain=.paloaltonetworks.com; expires=' + new Date(0).toUTCString();
		}
	}
if(referer != "Prisma" && referer != "CloudCortex" && referer != "Cortex" && referer != "Sase" && referer != "Unit" && referer != "Ngfw") {
    referer = 'Unit' ;
    sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
}
function callMainSitePrismaNavHTML(){
    
    var referrer_domain = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
    sessionStorage.setItem("domain",referrer_domain);
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderPrisma.prismaRenderer.html';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/prismasearch";
        }
    if(referer == 'CloudCortex'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=cortexcloud';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/cortexcloudsearch";	
    }
    if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderCortex.cortexRenderer.html';	
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/cortexsearch";	
    }
    if(referer == 'Sase'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderSase.saseRenderer.html';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/sasesearch";
    }
    if(referer == 'Unit'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=unit42';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/content/pan/en_US/search/unit42search";
		    }
    if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/ngfw-cdss-nav-renderer.php';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/ngfwcdsssearch";
    }
    httpGet(menu_url,'menu_html');
    document.getElementById('main-nav-menu-cont').removeAttribute("style");
}
function addStyle(styles) {            
    /* Create style document */
    var css = document.createElement('style');
    css.type = 'text/css';

    if (css.styleSheet) 
        css.styleSheet.cssText = styles;
    else 
        css.appendChild(document.createTextNode(styles));

    /* Append style to the tag name */
    document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(css);
}
function httpGet(theUrl,req_type) {
    if (window.XMLHttpRequest) { // code for IE7+, Firefox, Chrome, Opera, Safari
        xmlhttp=new XMLHttpRequest();
    } else {// code for IE6, IE5
        xmlhttp=new ActiveXObject("Microsoft.XMLHTTP");
    }
    xmlhttp.onreadystatechange=function()
    {
        if (xmlhttp.readyState==4 && xmlhttp.status==200)
        {
            if(req_type == 'menu_html'){
            var nav_text = xmlhttp.responseText.replaceAll('https://static.cloud.coveo.com/searchui/v2.9159/js/CoveoJsSearch.Lazy.min.js', '');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll('src="/', 'src="'+maindomain_lang+'/');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll("'/content", "'"+maindomain_lang+"/content");
                        
            document.getElementById("PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC").innerHTML = nav_text.replaceAll('href="/', 'href="'+maindomain_lang+'/');

            var lozad_back = document.getElementsByClassName('lozad-background');
            Array.prototype.forEach.call(lozad_back, function(el) {
            // Do stuff here
            var el_back_img_path = el.getAttribute('data-background-image');
            var first_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'");
            var last_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'",first_pos+1);
            el_back_img_path = el_back_img_path.substring(first_pos+1,last_pos);
            el.setAttribute("data-background-image",main_site_url+el_back_img_path);
            });
            const observer_lozad = lozad('.lozad, .lozad-background'); // lazy loads elements with default selector as '.lozad'
            observer_lozad.observe();
            }
            if(req_type == 'head_inline_css'){
            addStyle(xmlhttp.responseText);
            }
        }
    }
    xmlhttp.open("GET", theUrl, true );
    xmlhttp.send();    
}    
    
if(referer == 'Prisma' || referer == 'CloudCortex' || referer == 'Cortex' || referer == 'Sase' || referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
    const article = document.querySelector('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC');
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        article.dataset.type = 'prisma';
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    else if(referer == 'CloudCortex'){
        article.dataset.type = 'cloudcortex';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Sase'){
        article.dataset.type = 'sase';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Unit'){
        article.dataset.type = 'unit';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        article.dataset.type = 'ngfw';
    }
    //set class to default
    if(referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    callMainSitePrismaNavHTML();
}
</script>
<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->

              <h1>Threat Brief: SolarStorm and SUNBURST Customer Coverage</h1>

    </div>                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </section> 
    <section class="section blog-contents"> 
      <div class="pa blog-editor">
        <div class="l-container">
          <div class="be__wrapper">
            <div class="be__contents">
              <div class="be__contents-wrapper">
                <p class="wpml-ls-statics-post_translations wpml-ls">This post is also available in: 
    <span class="wpml-ls-slot-post_translations wpml-ls-item wpml-ls-item-ja wpml-ls-first-item wpml-ls-last-item wpml-ls-item-legacy-post-translations"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.jp/fireeye-solarstorm-sunburst/" class="wpml-ls-link"><span class="wpml-ls-native" lang="ja">日本語</span><span class="wpml-ls-display"><span class="wpml-ls-bracket"> (</span>Japanese<span class="wpml-ls-bracket">)</span></span></a></span></p><h2><a id="post-110239-_o3np16hjbfzv"></a>Executive Summary</h2>
<p>On Sunday, Dec. 13, FireEye released information related to a breach and data exfiltration originating from an unknown actor FireEye is calling UNC2452. Unit 42 tracks this and related activity as the group named SolarStorm, and has published an ATOM containing the observed techniques, IOCs and relevant courses of action in the <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/atoms/solarstorm/">Unit 42 ATOM Viewer</a>. According to FireEye, SolarStorm has compromised organizations across the globe via a supply chain attack that consists of a trojanized update file for the SolarWinds Orion Platform.</p>
<p>FireEye’s blog, “<a href="https://www.fireeye.com/blog/threat-research/2020/12/evasive-attacker-leverages-solarwinds-supply-chain-compromises-with-sunburst-backdoor.html">Highly Evasive Attacker Leverages SolarWinds Supply Chain to Compromise Multiple Global Victims with SUNBURST Backdoor</a>,” contains a wealth of useful information, all of which has been analyzed by Unit 42 researchers to help ensure Palo Alto Networks customers are protected.</p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Any organization utilizing SolarWinds Orion IT management software is potentially at risk from this threat. These organizations should immediately identify Orion systems in their network, determine if they are compromised with the SUNBURST backdoor and seek out further evidence of compromise. Instructions on how to perform these tasks using the <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/fireeye-solarstorm-sunburst/2">Palo Alto Networks Next Generation Firewall</a>, <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/fireeye-solarstorm-sunburst/3">Cortex XDR and XSOAR</a> are available in this report, as well as <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/fireeye-solarstorm-sunburst/4">additional resources and indicators of compromise</a> (IOCs). Palo Alto Networks has also launched <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/solarstorm-rapid-response">SolarStorm Rapid Response Programs</a>. </span></p>
<p>The details of this attack and its impact continue to evolve. We will update this report with new details as they become available.</p>
<h2><a id="post-110239-_gwkv3l2ifbxv"></a>What’s Known About SolarStorm and SUNBURST</h2>
<ul>
<li>SolarStorm specifically targeted supply chains during their attack on SolarWinds’ Orion IT performance and statistics monitoring software.</li>
<li>SolarStorm is a highly skilled threat actor, with a significant operational security mindset, as can be observed in its post-exploitation activity.</li>
<li>SolarWinds recently filed an SEC report indicating that, while they have over 300,000 customers, fewer than 18,000 customers were running the trojanized version of the Orion software.</li>
<li>SolarStorm threat actors created a legitimate digitally signed backdoor, SUNBURST, as a trojanized version of a SolarWinds Orion plug-in. The trojanized software acts as a powerful supply chain infiltration mechanism for delivery.</li>
<li>SUNBURST has been observed delivering multiple payloads, mostly focused on memory-only droppers, such as the FireEye-dubbed TEARDROP and Cobalt Strike BEACON.</li>
<li>SUNBURST’s command and control (C2) traffic masquerades as legitimate Orion Improvement Program traffic.</li>
<li>FireEye has released <a href="https://github.com/fireeye/sunburst_countermeasures">signatures</a> and specific indicators to help identify SolarStorm’s activity.</li>
</ul>
<p>FireEye’s research has been a cornerstone in providing not only useful signatures, but also indicators which help with tracking and hunting for SolarStorm activity. A synopsis of those indicators is included below.</p>
<h4><a id="post-110239-_xj4gt0l5e76f"></a><strong>SUNBURST</strong></h4>
<p>At the time of this publication, the Windows Installer Patch file including the trojanized version of the SolarWinds Orion product was still reachable:</p>
<p>Filename: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">SolarWinds-Core-v2019.4.5220-Hotfix5.msp</span><br />
SHA256: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">d0d626deb3f9484e649294a8dfa814c5568f846d5aa02d4cdad5d041a29d5600</span></p>
<p>This installer contains:</p>
<ul>
<li>Legitimate SolarWinds Orion update components.</li>
<li>A digitally signed SUNBURST backdoor, and its legitimate configuration file:
<ul>
<li>SHA256: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">32519b85c0b422e4656de6e6c41878e95fd95026267daab4215ee59c107d6c77</span>
<ul>
<li>Filename: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">SolarWinds.Orion.Core.BusinessLayer.dll</span></li>
<li>Certificate SN: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">0f:e9:73:75:20:22:a6:06:ad:f2:a3:6e:34:5d:c0:ed</span></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>SHA256: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">efbec6863f4330dbb702cc43a85a0a7c29d79fde0f7d66eac9a3be43493cab4f</span>
<ul>
<li>Filename: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">SolarWinds.Orion.Core.BusinessLayer.dll.config</span></li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
<p>The infrastructure related to this series of attacks includes:</p>
<ul>
<li>Trojanized update file hosted at:
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxps://downloads.solarwinds[.]com/solarwinds/CatalogResources/Core/2019.4/2019.4.5220.20574/SolarWinds-Core-v2019.4.5220-Hotfix5.msp</span></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>DGA-generated C2s as subdomains of:
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">avsvmcloud[.]com</span></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>C2 domains found during SUNBURST incidents, including CNAME records, or subsequent phases of the incident, such as BEACON components:
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">freescanonline[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">deftsecurity[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">thedoccloud[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">websitetheme[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">highdatabase[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">incomeupdate[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">databasegalore[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">panhardware[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Zupertech[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Virtualdataserver[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">digitalcollege[.]org</span></li>
<li><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">solartrackingsystem[.]net</span></li>
<li><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">webcodez[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">seobundlekit[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">virtualwebdata[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">lcomputers[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">avsvmcloud[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Mobilnweb[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">kubecloud[.]com</span></li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
<h4><strong>TEARDROP</strong></h4>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">SUNBURST deployed several different payloads, and in at least one instance, a memory-only dropper FireEye dubbed TEARDROP to deploy a Cobalt Strike BEACON. During analysis of the information available, Unit 42 identified related activity involving TEARDROP malware that was used to execute a customized Cobalt Strike BEACON. This sample contains a beacon request to the </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">previously unreported domain</span></i><span style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"> mobilnweb[.]com</span>.</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">The TEARDROP DLL has a SHA256 of: </span><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">118189f90da3788362fe85eafa555298423e21ec37f147f3bf88c61d4cd46c51</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">and contains a beacon request for the URI /2019/Person-With-Parnters-Brands-Our/ with the User-Agent Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/85.0.4183.83 Safari/537.36. Within that same configuration, we also observed an additional URI setting containing the string /2019/This-Person-Two-Join-With/.</span></p>
<h2><a id="post-110239-_pmlitrmlfgia"></a>Protecting Our Customers</h2>
<p>As of the time of writing, based on signatures and observables that have been released, Palo Alto Networks customers are protected across our product ecosystem, with specific protections deployed or being deployed in the following products and subscriptions for the Next-Generation Firewall (NGFW). <span style="font-weight: 400;">It is imperative for customers to employ the </span><a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/best-practices"><span style="font-weight: 400;">best practices for Palo Alto Networks products</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> in order to ensure your appliances are configured in a manner best suited for your protection.</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Due to the nature of these attacks, we recommend our customers perform the following searches immediately. If you are unable, Palo Alto Networks </span><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/solarstorm-rapid-response"><span style="font-weight: 400;">will help you locate</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> SolarWinds Orion servers </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">owned by your organization and assess whether you’ve been compromised free of charge. After we’ve completed our analysis, we’ll provide you with a SolarStorm Assessment Report brought to you by Expanse and Crypsis.</span></p>
<h6><strong><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xdr">Cortex XDR</a></strong></h6>
<p><a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xdr/cortex-xdr-pro-admin/endpoint-security/endpoint-security-concepts/endpoint-protection-modules.html">Cortex XDR customers are protected</a> using the product’s WildFire integration, as well as through Local Analysis, the Password Theft Protection module and the Behavioral Threat Protection (BTP) engine. Protections are continually being evaluated, developed and deployed for Cortex XDR.</p>
<h6><strong><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/managed-threat-hunting">Cortex XDR Managed Threat Hunting</a></strong></h6>
<p>Our Cortex XDR Managed Threat Hunting Team (MTH) has proactively searched all Cortex XDR Pro customer logs to identify potentially impacted organizations and provide them an assessment of their risk.<span style="font-weight: 400;"> </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">Leverage the</span><a href="https://blog.paloaltonetworks.com/security-operations/cortex-xsoar-solarstorm-sunburst/"> <span style="font-weight: 400;">power of automation with Cortex XSOAR</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> to speed up the discovery of SolarWind installations within your network, uncover signs of potential SolarStorm activity and automate response actions such as the quarantining of compromised endpoints.</span> <span style="font-weight: 400;">  </span></p>
<h6><strong><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/products/secure-the-network/wildfire">WildFire</a> (NGFW security subscription)</strong></h6>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Customers using WildFire are protected from downloading known SUNBURST backdoor files and Cobalt Strike BEACON files associated with SolarStorm.</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Gap analysis and threat hunting leveraging the FireEye-provided </span><a href="https://virustotal.github.io/yara/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Yara</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> signatures and observables has enabled Unit 42 researchers to identify potential malware samples. We continue to seek out new malware associated with SolarStorm, build and deploy protections for them within </span><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/products/secure-the-network/wildfire"><span style="font-weight: 400;">WildFire</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">. </span></p>
<h6><strong><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/autofocus">AutoFocus</a></strong></h6>
<p>AutoFocus customers can track SolarStorm’s activity in the tags <a href="https://autofocus.paloaltonetworks.com/#/tag/Unit42.SolarStorm">SolarStorm</a>, <a href="https://autofocus.paloaltonetworks.com/#/tag/Unit42.SUPERNOVA">SUPERNOVA</a>, <a href="https://autofocus.paloaltonetworks.com/#/tag/Unit42.TEARDROP"><span style="font-weight: 400;">TEARDROP</span></a> and <a href="https://autofocus.paloaltonetworks.com/#/tag/Unit42.SUNBURST">SUNBURST</a>.</p>
<h6><strong><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/iot-security">IoT Security</a> </strong><strong>(NGFW security subscriptions)</strong></h6>
<p>The IoT Security subscription has the capability of identifying SolarWinds servers. These devices are being added to the IoT Security user portal UI, and the Device-ID attribute will be pushed to PAN-OS. These devices will be displayed to users as "SolarWinds Network Management Device" within the IoT Security user portal UI. In PAN-OS, users will see the Device-ID attribute "Profile" = "SolarWinds Network Management Device". This feature will be enabled for all IoT Security customers this week.</p>
<h6><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/products/secure-the-network/subscriptions/threat-prevention">Threat Prevention </a><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/products/threat-detection-and-prevention/dns-security">DNS Security</a> (NGFW security subscriptions)</h6>
<p>Threat Prevention and DNS Security provide protection against C2 beacons and associated traffic. Protections are continually being evaluated, developed and deployed for Threat Prevention subscription.</p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">The following threat prevention signatures have been added with Content version 8354:</span></p>
<table>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td><b>Snort Rule</b></td>
<td><b>PANW UTID</b></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Backdoor.BEACON_5.snort</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">86237</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Backdoor.BEACON_6.snort</span></td>

<p style="text-align: center;"><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">Table 1: Snort to PANW UTID</span></i></p>
<h6><strong><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/products/threat-detection-and-prevention/web-security">URL Filtering</a> </strong><strong>(NGFW security subscription)</strong></h6>
<p>As of the time of writing, associated infrastructure described in this blog have accurate verdicts of malware.</p>
<p><strong><em>Continue Reading: <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/fireeye-solarstorm-sunburst/2">SolarStorm Response With Next-Generation Firewall</a></em></strong></p>

    <div class="l-container">
            <h2>Related Malware Resources</h2>
      <div class="blog-slider" id="blogSlider"> 
                    <div class="pa l-card l-card--slider" >
              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/07_Malware_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="lozad" alt="Pictorial representation of unusual malware. A glowing pink warning triangle with an exclamation point on a screen with the word &quot;malware.&quot; There are other text elements on the screen suggesting a coding environment. The colors are neon blue and pink." decoding="async" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/07_Malware_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/07_Malware_Category_1920x900-1493x700.jpg 1493w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/07_Malware_Category_1920x900-768x360.jpg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/07_Malware_Category_1920x900-1536x720.jpg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/07_Malware_Category_1920x900.jpg 1920w" sizes="(max-width: 786px) 100vw, 786px" />                </figure> 
                            </div>
              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="fireeye-solarstorm-sunburst:related-resources:Off the Beaten Path: Recent Unusual Malware:Threat Research"><span class=""><img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-threat-research.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Research</span></a>                        <span class="post-pub-date"><time datetime="2025-03-14T10:00:04+00:00">March 14, 2025</time></span>
                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/unusual-malware/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="fireeye-solarstorm-sunburst:related-resources:Off the Beaten Path: Recent Unusual Malware">
                    <h4 class="post-title">Off the Beaten Path: Recent Unusual Malware</h4>

                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="292" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/09-3-Stately-Taurus-1616x600-1-786x292.png" class="lozad" alt="Pictorial representation of APT Stately Taurus.               <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-actor-groups/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="fireeye-solarstorm-sunburst:related-resources:Stately Taurus Activity in Southeast Asia Links to Bookworm Malware:Threat Actor Groups"><span class=""><img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/threat-actor-groups.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Actor Groups</span></a>                        <span class="post-pub-date"><time datetime="2025-02-20T11:00:23+00:00">February 20, 2025</time></span>
                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/stately-taurus-uses-bookworm-malware/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="fireeye-solarstorm-sunburst:related-resources:Stately Taurus Activity in Southeast Asia Links to Bookworm Malware">
                    <h4 class="post-title">Stately Taurus Activity in Southeast Asia Links to Bookworm Malware</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/stately-taurus/" title="Stately Taurus" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="fireeye-solarstorm-sunburst:related-resources:Stately Taurus Activity in Southeast Asia Links to Bookworm Malware:Stately Taurus">Stately Taurus</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/dll-sideloading/" title="DLL Sideloading" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="fireeye-solarstorm-sunburst:related-resources:Stately Taurus Activity in Southeast Asia Links to Bookworm Malware:DLL Sideloading">DLL Sideloading</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/bookworm/" title="Bookworm" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="fireeye-solarstorm-sunburst:related-resources:Stately Taurus Activity in Southeast Asia Links to Bookworm Malware:Bookworm">Bookworm</a>
				</li></ul>                </div>
                <div class="card-content__link">
                                    <a class="hyperlink" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/stately-taurus-uses-bookworm-malware/" title="Stately Taurus Activity in Southeast Asia Links to Bookworm Malware" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="fireeye-solarstorm-sunburst:related-resources:Stately Taurus Activity in Southeast Asia Links to Bookworm Malware:read now">
                    Read now                    <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-right-arrow-withtail.svg" alt="Right arrow">
                  </a>
                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
                                <div class="pa l-card l-card--slider" >
              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/03_Malware_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="lozad" alt="Pictorial representation of macOS infostealers. Laptop on a desk displaying advanced cybersecurity software interface with vibrant red graphics, in a dimly lit room." decoding="async" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/03_Malware_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/03_Malware_Category_1920x900-1493x700.jpg 1493w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/03_Malware_Category_1920x900-768x360.jpg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/03_Malware_Category_1920x900-1536x720.jpg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/03_Malware_Category_1920x900.jpg 1920w" sizes="(max-width: 786px) 100vw, 786px" />                </figure> 
                            </div>
              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="fireeye-solarstorm-sunburst:related-resources:Stealers on the Rise: A Closer Look at a Growing macOS Threat:Threat Research"><span class=""><img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-threat-research.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Research</span></a>                        <span class="post-pub-date"><time datetime="2025-02-04T11:00:12+00:00">February 4, 2025</time></span>
                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/macos-stealers-growing/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="fireeye-solarstorm-sunburst:related-resources:Stealers on the Rise: A Closer Look at a Growing macOS Threat">

                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">

					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/macos/" title="macOS" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="fireeye-solarstorm-sunburst:related-resources:Stealers on the Rise: A Closer Look at a Growing macOS Threat:macOS">MacOS</a>

              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/14_Overview_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="lozad" alt="Digital representation of jailbreaking DeepSeek. A dynamic, multicolored wave pattern with luminous particles, set against a dark background." decoding="async" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/14_Overview_1920x900-786x368.jpg 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/14_Overview_1920x900-1493x700.jpg 1493w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/14_Overview_1920x900-768x360.jpg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/14_Overview_1920x900-1536x720.jpg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/14_Overview_1920x900.jpg 1920w" sizes="(max-width: 786px) 100vw, 786px" />                </figure> 
                            </div>
              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="fireeye-solarstorm-sunburst:related-resources:Recent Jailbreaks Demonstrate Emerging Threat to DeepSeek:Threat Research"><span class=""><img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-threat-research.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Research</span></a>                        <span class="post-pub-date"><time datetime="2025-01-30T21:30:36+00:00">January 30, 2025</time></span>
